entry.title: üéì [Deep Dive] Practical useEffect Use Cases
entry.content:
üéØ Why This Matters

In the previous post, we introduced the basic concepts behind useEffect. Now, let‚Äôs dive into practical examples to understand why we need it ‚Äî and what issues can arise if we ignore it.

üìå Use Case 1: Fetching API Data

‚ùå Without useEffect (Wrong)

function BadComponent() {
  const [data, setData] = useState(null);

  fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
    .then(res => res.json())
    .then(data => setData(data));

  return <div>{JSON.stringify(data)}</div>;
}

  • Every render triggers a fetch

  • setData() causes re-render ‚Üí infinite loop

  • App becomes slow, unstable, or crashes

‚úÖ With useEffect (Correct)

function GoodComponent() {
  const [data, setData] = useState(null);

  useEffect(() => {
    fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
      .then(res => res.json())
      .then(data => setData(data));
  }, []);

  return <div>{JSON.stringify(data)}</div>;
}
  • fetch runs only once on mount
  • No repeated API calls

üìå Use Case 2: Setting up Event Listeners

‚ùå Without useEffect (Wrong)

function BadResizeComponent() {
  window.addEventListener('resize', () => {
    console.log(window.innerWidth);
  });

  return <div>Resize the window!</div>;
}
  • A new event listener is added on every render
  • Leads to memory leak and performance drop

‚úÖ With useEffect (Correct)

function GoodResizeComponent() {
  useEffect(() => {
    const handleResize = () => {
      console.log(window.innerWidth);
    };

    window.addEventListener('resize', handleResize);

    return () => window.removeEventListener('resize', handleResize);
  }, []);

  return <div>Resize the window!</div>;
}
  • Listener added once
  • Listener cleaned up properly when component unmounts

üìå Use Case 3: Timers (setInterval / setTimeout)

‚ùå Without useEffect (Wrong)

function BadTimerComponent() {
  setInterval(() => {
    console.log('Tick');
  }, 1000);

  return <div>Timer running...</div>;
}
  • Every render creates a new interval
  • Leads to multiple timers ticking at once

‚úÖ With useEffect (Correct)

function GoodTimerComponent() {
  useEffect(() => {
    const timer = setInterval(() => {
      console.log('Tick');
    }, 1000);

    return () => clearInterval(timer); // cleanup
  }, []);

  return <div>Timer running...</div>;
}
  • Only one interval
  • Cleared on unmount

üß™ Understanding useEffect Comparison and Triggering

üíº How Dependency Comparison Works?

React‚Äôs useEffect hook uses shallow comparison for its dependency array:

üßê Primitive Values (number, string, boolean)

useEffect(() => {
  // Runs when userId changes
}, [userId]); // Compares with `===`
  • Uses strict equality (===) comparison
  • Effect runs only when the value actually changes

ü§î When useEffect Triggers?

  • First Render (Mount)
  • Always runs after initial render

üí° Subsequent Renders

  • Runs after render completes

-Only if shallow comparison detects changes in dependencies

‚≠ïÔ∏è The Render Cycle

  • Component renders (due to state/props change)

  • React compares each dependency with previous values

  • Effect executes if any dependency changed

üîë Key Points

  • useEffect runs asynchronously after render completes

  • Parent re-renders will cause child effects to re-evaluate

  • State updates (useState) trigger re-renders which may trigger effects

entry.title: üéì [Deep Dive] About useEffect
entry.content:
üìù Why Do We Need useEffect in React?

Understand What It Is, Why It Matters, and How It Works

‚úÖ Introduction

React‚Äôs function components are clean and powerful, but they come with a twist ‚Äî no lifecycle methods like componentDidMount. So how do we fetch data, set up timers, or listen to events?

That‚Äôs where useEffect comes in.

üîç What is useEffect?

useEffect is a React Hook that lets you perform side effects in function components.

üíª Common side effects include:

  • Fetching data from APIs
  • Setting up subscriptions or timers
  • Listening to window resize or scroll events
  • Manually updating the DOM

üõ†Ô∏è Basic Syntax

useEffect(() => {
  // your side effect logic here
}, [dependencies]);

üìà Example:

import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react';

function ExampleComponent() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

  useEffect(() => {
    console.log('Count changed:', count);
  }, [count]); // runs when `count` changes

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>
        Add +1
      </button>
    </div>
  );
}

üîÅ Three types of the dependency array

  • [] ‚Üí run once (on mount)
  • [count] ‚Üí run when count changes
  • no array ‚Üí run on every render

üí• What happens if you don‚Äôt use useEffect?

‚ùå Fetching data directly inside the component body

function BadComponent() {
  const [data, setData] = useState(null);

  // ‚ùå This will run every render ‚Äî bad!
  fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
    .then(res => res.json())
    .then(data => setData(data));

  return <div>{JSON.stringify(data)}</div>;
}

üö® What goes wrong?

  • fetch() runs ‚Üí setData() updates state

  • State update ‚Üí triggers re-render

  • Re-render the whole component and it will run fetch() again ‚Üí another state update‚Ä¶

  • üîÅ Infinite loop of requests ‚Üí bad for performance and may crash the app-

‚úÖ Fetching data with useEffect

function GoodComponent() {
  const [data, setData] = useState(null);

  useEffect(() => {
    fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
  }, []); 


  return (
      return <div>{JSON.stringify(data)}</div>;
  );
}
  • In this case, we use 
    useEffect(() => {
  fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
}, []);
    • Only runs once when the component mounts (first render)
    • Never re-runs, even if state/props change
    • So we avoid the Infinite loop of requests like above code

‚ùì Q&A: Common Questions About useEffect

1. What is the purpose of the cleanup function in useEffect?

In useEffect, you can return a function ‚Äî called the cleanup function ‚Äî that React will call when the component unmounts or before re-running the effect due to dependency changes.

The purpose of cleanup is to remove or cancel any ongoing side effects that should no longer be active, such as:

  • Removing event listeners
  • Clearing timers (setInterval or setTimeout)
  • Unsubscribing from subscriptions
  • Closing WebSocket connections

Without proper cleanup, you risk memory leaks, unexpected behaviors, and performance issues.

useEffect(() => {
  function handleResize() {
    console.log('Window resized:', window.innerWidth);
  }

  window.addEventListener('resize', handleResize);

  return () => {
    window.removeEventListener('resize', handleResize);
  };
}, []);

2. Can you have multiple useEffect hooks in the same component?

‚úÖ Yes, absolutely!

You can (and often should) use multiple useEffect hooks within a single component. Each useEffect should ideally manage one specific side effect.

This makes your code cleaner, easier to read, and easier to maintain.

Example:

useEffect(() => {
  console.log('Effect for count');
}, [count]);

useEffect(() => {
  console.log('Effect for name');
}, [name]);

Each effect operates independently, depending on its specific dependencies.

3. If there are multiple useEffect, what is their execution order?

React runs multiple useEffect hooks in the order they appear in your code ‚Äî top to bottom.

Even if different effects depend on different variables, the order is determined by their position in the component.

Example:

useEffect(() => {
  console.log('First Effect');
}, []);

useEffect(() => {
  console.log('Second Effect');
}, []);

useEffect(() => {
  console.log('Third Effect');
}, []);

Output after first render:

First Effect
Second Effect
Third Effect

Cleanup functions, if any, are called in reverse order before running the new effects.

entry.content:
You‚Äôll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.
